dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heat that has mass. That rises off the parched earth in shimmering waves. After a moment, we see what appear to be figures coming out of the haze, one by one. A family with their few belongings: HASARI PAL, 33, his wife, ALOKA, 28, and their children, daughter, AMRITA, 13, sons MANOOJ and SHAMBU, 11 and 9; HASARI'S MOTHER and FATHER. They embark toward the night, the rising sun behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari's Father passes a gourd of precious water. Hasari serves the children first. Shambu gulps entirely too much, the others forcing him to stop by a unified force of will. Embarrassed, he passes the cup to his brother, who sips, as does his sister. Aloka barely wets her lips, insisting on leaving the last drops for Hasari. And now, a rooster tail of dust rises up behind the approaching bus and the old parents bid farewell to their son's family. There is an intense sadness at leaving the land and Hasari's Mother clings to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send money soon. His Mother nods, as Hasari erupts in a small cough which, by habit, he suppresses. His Mother crushes Aloka to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the children out of your sight. Not for a moment. Now the children. She wants to keep them here even as the old man touches her, reminding her she must let them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help your parents. Don't fight with each other. And, Manooj, stay away from the cinema, do you hear? Shambu, his eyes big as saucers, whispers to his grandma...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go. There are bad men with long knives who steal children. That does it: Hasari's   Mother dissolves in tears, but the old man nevertheless  unlooses her insistently from the children. Aloka and   the children get on the bus as the old man embraces his  son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's journey to the end of his obligations is a very long road. Yours begins here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not an empty inch inside the little vehicle or on top.  The passengers are silent. A woman breast feeds a baby.  Several passengers fan themselves. Many sleep. The Pals squeeze wearily into the rear seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his neighbor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our farm has died, so we are moving to Calcutta to become rich! Hasari and Aloka look  at each other: If only it were the pursuit of wealth and  not survival. The woman under- stands. And now the   BUS GRINDS forward and the Pals loo back. Hasari coughs,   suppresses it... as silence falls. The elder Pals stand huddled   together in the dust and w see, nestled behind a boulder   at the roadside, a tiny, blue flower -- beautiful and   fragile, but like all thin alive, determined to live...   and we hear the sound of a DOZEN VOICES CHANTING a quiet   mantra in unison as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This flower floats gently in a bowl of water. The TITLES END as we PULL BACK SLOWLY to reveal a dozen Anglos, several Indians, and one Kenyan seated cross-legged before an aging Yogi, who's quietly urging the suppli- cants to find "their light, allow your white light to fill your spirit's eye." Above, ceiling fans move the air.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As we PAN the group, we see that everyone has his/her eyes closed in earnest meditation... until we COME TO an American, MAX LOEB, 29, who pops open first his right eye -- looks to his right and left -- closes his right eye and opens his left eye -- looks left and right... and then, instead of continuing the mantra and the search for his white light, expels a stream of air through his pursed lips, making a vibrating, flatulent sound, one indicative of sizeable frustration and dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get serious. Around him, other single eyes pop open, searching for the source of this unmeditative sound. Max nods and smiles a wry smile as if to say: This just ain't doin' it for me, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max closes the trumpet case and starts chucking his clothes and books in a knapsack and a small valise. We notice the Hebrew letter chai on a gold chain around his neck. His girl friend, BETSY KAHN, overdressed somewhat in an Indian style, endeavors to exercise the inner peace she's been pursuing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God, you never give anything enough time! What did you expect in five days, Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only what    they promise in the brochure:     Inner peace, serenity, and a nice    chant that gets rid of this rock    in my gut. E.S.T., they do you in    a weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would really appreciate it if you wouldn't be terribly glib just now, Max. That's okay with Max, who's willing to eschew communica- tion of all kinds and just finish heaving his stuff in the valise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I to assume you'll be at the airport in Calcutta a week from tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible to predict, Betsy Ilene Kahn. Maybe you better give me my ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw you, Max -- I paid for it! How many times am I going to let you walk out on me and come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think only you can answer that, Betsy Ilene Kahn. She slaps him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think that's an appropriate way to get rid of your Western rage, Bets? She swings at him again.   He catches her hand hard in hi fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One slap is romantic. Two would call for retaliation... Lend me a hundred dollars. She yanks free, begins to chant her mantra as he grabs his knapsack and valise and goes out the door.  Now, she's silent and, in the simplest sense, deeply hurt. She can't help herself; she cares. We STAY WITH  her a moment as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool, lush hills. A little pack of single-engine two- and four-seaters. Max, in shorts and University of Miami T-shirt, hot, sweaty, appears around a bend in the approach road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small service desk. A CLERK, who doubles as Ground Control on the microphone, passing on the prevailing wind and the active runway. We hear the STATIC-BACKED VOICE of a PILOT, giving his call numbers, then announcing he's clear for immediate takeoff on the active runway. The Clerk CLICKS off and finds Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'? The Clerk gives Max a warm smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to walk into a little airport just about like this one and ask the guy at the counter the following question. Ready? The Clerk nods; he's at Max's ervice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the next flight to anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Bombay. Tomorrow, at one o'clock in the afternoon. A beat --- the Clerk with his smile, Max with his, one simply warm, the other giving off simmering heat.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Max sits on the ground, up against the building, playing a jazz line quietly and rather well on his trumpet. A pair of well-shod feet ENTER the FRAME. Max looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rubicund face of VEEJAY CHATTERGEE, 50, and more British than Churchill. Behind him, his cherubic wife, RAVI... and making her way toward the enclave of small planes, their daughter, MANUBAI, 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, are you looking for a way out of here? We have an extra seat. Where are you wanting to go? Max's eyes flick from Veejay to the back view of Manubai as she continues on and back to Veejay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wanting to go wherever you're wanting to take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is crammed into the back seat with the plump Ravi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see now that, contrary to our assumption that Veejay would be in the left seat, it's Manubai who's flying the plane. The NOISE of the ENGINE forces them to speak somewhat loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were among the fortunate back in '48.  We got out of East Bengal before partition destroyed so many. We make mattresses. The Rajah Double Spring. Veejay has an old flask out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have a flight attendant on this flight... (passing the flask) Are you a musician, Mr. Loeb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unattached trumpet player and recently-certified associate guru. As he takes a hit   on   the flask, Max's eye focuses on little mirror on   the   dash. In it he can see Manubai's eyes. If we  were   to   judge by what he sees in them, s doesn't find him   the   least bit amusing. He smiles his smile at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge bridge dominates the skyline. The train     trundl to a stop, its WHISTLE clearing the way. People     hang its sides, sit on the roof... and now flood the    platfo flowing into the station, clearing a view for us    of th Pals, clinging to their baggage in the middle of    this human anthill.

dialogues.speaker: THEM, (MOVING)
dialogues.text: Hands reach out with sweets to sell, with tea, asking for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared? No -- why? This is very exciting. As soon as we get to our friend's house, everything will be fine. But, despite Hasari's charade of confidence, they (and we) are overwhelmed by the size of the station and the desperate energy of the humanity around them. As they press on, a small beggar woman huddled on the platform turns her eyes eerily on Manooj... as a deformed hand stretches INTO the FRAME. Aloka senses someone: A beggar, face half-hidden and eaten away by leprosy. This terrifying image presses the boys tightly to their mother and moves Hasari to encircle Armita with one hand and attempt to wrap the other three inside the embrace of his other hand. It does not seem possible that he can protect all of them against the predatory eyes watching them. He moves them quickly to a wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait right here. Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: WITH HASARI
dialogues.text: He moves to a line of VENDORS, shows a piece of paper to one, as he digs out his precious screw of money to make a purchase of sweets from the Vendor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, can you direct me to my friend at this address? We are to stay with him. The Vendor gives the address a look, shows it to the Vendor next to him. Both look at Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no such address as this in Calcutta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course    it is possible! I have lived here    all my life. You are new. Who     would know if a place exists or    does not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombay, perhaps. Delhi.     Look there.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dear God, what now? Stunned, Hasari hands Vendor #1 a rupee and, with the sweets, turns back to his family, his face going through a magical transformation as he prepares to suggest to the family that all is well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few clean and cared-for Ambassador cars sweep into the gateway of the Grand Hotel, past a gateman.

dialogues.speaker: FEET
dialogues.text: Feet tramping the pulsating tarmac, sending up dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pals, scared, dispirited, weary, consumed by the crowd. They've been walking a long  time. Shambu cries; Aloka tries to ease his fear. They  stop numbly at the edge of the park, put their bundles down against a long wall. Across the way, a thin policeman shares a cigarette with a group of traders. There is a deeply fearful look in Hasari's eyes, a look he is having difficulty controlling now. He needs to revive the family's confidence. He takes out his precious bundle of rupees and gives one to Manooj. Manooj, though, is fixed on the cinema across the street. Hasari indicates a stall just across the main road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manooj, go and get some fruit. Come straight back. Delighted with his task, Manooj sets off, his eyes on the marquee of the theater with its huge cardboard cutout of Kumar Kapur, starring in Hot Gun. Hasari calls out to him to watch where he's going; the mere crossing of the street is a potential parental nightmare. A hand ruffles Manooj's head and a TALL MAN with dark eyes and a sweet smile comes at the boy's anxious parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, hello, brother. Bihar, am I correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, how did you know?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hasari is torn between speaking to the man and watching his son's incredible journey across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me say only that the terrible malevolence that has visited your part of the country affects us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years without rain. Nothing came out of the earth but debts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible. And now, the    family on the street. It is not    acceptable. (smile widens) And if I can't help, my   name is not Mr. Gangooly... Which,   blessedly, it is. And now a smile as full as the sky above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brick slides out of the wall. We're BEHIND the brick and see Gangooly's soft face as he reaches in and pulls out a key. The street is small and empty.  Though the houses are nothing much, to the Pals, they look like palaces. Manooj and Shambu run about in delight. Gangooly motions for quiet. With a flourish, he  opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gangooly enters, glances around, waves the Pals in. They're amazed. There's a cage occupied by two parrots. In one corner, a small altar dedicated to the goddess Lakshmi is decorated with some flowers and, behind a torn, plastic curtain in a corner, part kitchen, part wash place, containing a tap with running water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be free -- look around. On the faces of the family is one thought: Is it possible? Amrita goes right to the parrots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll need feeding. Give them seed. But don't spoil them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He bows briefly before the altar as he moves to the washing area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, one of the miracles of life in the city. One and two... He turns on the tap and a stream of brown WATER GURGLES out. The Pals are hypnotized, the fists around their hearts begin to ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy water from the Ganges! Flows out forever. Come -- touch it. Manooj and Shambu put their hands under the tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink! It's as pure as the dew on Shiva's lips. They drink. Gangooly claps in delight... and beckons Hasari aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, this place is yours for two weeks. My cousin, Moti, is away, traveling. Normally, the rent takes fifty rupees for a week, but for a brother, forty. No, don't thank me. Hasari pulls out his little screw of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have only seventy-five, but as soon as I have work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the fifty, pay the rest next week. You'll find work, I trust you. Aren't I from Bihar, too?  Yes. And the money is in his hand.   He joins his hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are pleased? Then Mr. Gangooly is pleased. It's how I am.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns on his heel and he's gone. For a moment, the Pals are still, swept from the brink of catastrophe to salvation... and now, as one, they release their sheer and utter joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ravi and Veejay leading Max up the grand staircase, Manubai in the foyer, looking after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ravi leads the way into a lovely guest bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope this is all right. The room hasn't been aired or the bed turned, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he doesn't care about that, do you, Max? Here, look here. Veejay opens a little cupboard, stocked with liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself. Be comfortable. Ravi, come on, go, go, let's leave the young man to himself. Obediently, Ravi goes.   Veejay follows.   Max goes to th window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beautiful Manubai in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: He lies down on the bed.   He's found Nirvana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Hasari who watches now. There's LAUGHTER from Aloka and Amrita. Joyful SHOUTS from the boys. Hasari is alone in the main room, on his knees, in front of the pile of their baggage and bundles. He turns his atten- tion from the laughter to a just-opened, old suitcase. He takes out a small tea box. Opens it delicately.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It's full of something brown. He  pushes his fingers in and feels this bit of earth with a tenderness that's almost religious, puts a pinch to his nose and breathes it in. The LAUGHTER and SHOUTING  from the bathing area is GROWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shambu is paddling near the tap. Aloka is bending over the drain and Amrita is rinsing her heavy, dark hair with a pot. Manooj is nearby, rubbing himself with an old towel. Hasari enters unnoticed and looks at the group with tenderness... and with gratitude for their good fortune. A MAN, red with anger, yanks the curtain aside, stares. The family freezes. Aloka's hair drips unnoticed on her sari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?   Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Pal, Hasari. Mr. Gangooly rented this space to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gangooly.   You must be his cousin, Mr. Moti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know any Gangooly and my name is Binal and this is my home -- get out! The furious Binal, followed by the Pals, goes into the main part of the room. A small crowd has been attracted by the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is true. We paid him a deposit of fifty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man goes out because he has to work, and some beggar tries to move in while his back is turned.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This while Binal has begun to throw things out onto the street, though this cleansing of his home doesn't stop him from picking up a stick. The odd sympathizer meets with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, should I suffer if they are so stupid to jump into the first mouth that wants to eat them? He turns with the stick on Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky I don't kill you! Hasari looks at Manooj, who drops his eyes. They collect the remainder of their possessions and hurry out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of neighbors. There's a suppressed violence in the air. A man pushes Aloka. Sweat streaming down his face, Hasari confronts the man. A WOMAN pushes the men apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the river. Try to squeeze in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calcutta broiling: Buses, vendors, carts, rickshaws, children beg at car windows. The Pals stand, uncertain, and for the first time a rickshaw fills Hasari's eye, carrying two passengers. But now he shoulders his burden and leads the family toward the river. We HOLD until they grow small against the setting sun, gleaming red against the white domes of the Victoria Monument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving through the dark, a figure, touching things, looking at photographs of the Chattergees. We hear a MUFFLED DIALOGUE mixed with the SINGING a la Dean Martin of "Everybody Loves Somebody Sometime": "Goddamn it, boy, what's the matter with you? -- "Everybody loves somebody sometime" -- "Go for it, son!" -- "Sure, Dad, whatever you say, Dad." -- "Everybody falls in love somehow" -- "You're the dad, Dad." Now, a humidor. Max opens it, takes out a cigar, takes two. Takes five. Senses someone. Turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ravi in her bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starving. He gives her his best saint's smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you don't want to eat those awful cigars. Come with me, we'll wake up the cook, she'll fix you something proper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the window, we see the bleary-eyed cook laying out food as Ravi chatters away at Max, he with a beatific grin on his face as he feeds himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridge etched against the dawn sky. The corpse of an indigent is collected and put on a cart.

dialogues.speaker: MANOOJ
dialogues.text: With his eyes open, watching the dead man being removed.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY
dialogues.text: After their humiliating flight, they found refuge here. Tiny figures huddled together with their baggage and bundles, near a tree, not far from the steps that dip down to the smooth water. Hasari's eyes, too, are on the dead man, that warning. He kneels beside Manooj, strokes him. The boy's eyes turns to the man's, wondering if the man can provide for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let it frighten you. You have to be brave. I know we'll find work today. Fear and doubt fill Manooj's eyes.   He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari at the gates, the family huddled together in the b.g. The man behind the gate shakes his head, points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of a hundred men stretches from a door. Hasari is on the edge of panic, but when he turns to the family, he's wearing his confident smile. As before, he gathers the family into the protectorate of his arms and guides them onward. As he pushes off into the sea of humanity, we PULL BACK AND UP, FILLING the FRAME WITH street upon street, disappearing Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: FROM STREET
dialogues.text: Two plump men in shirt sleeves look coolly at Hasari. The elder shakes his head. The younger shows Hasari the door. Outside, an increasingly desperate Hasari finds Aloka before a small shrine, saying a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloka huddled with Manooj and Amrita. Hasari talking to the owner of a small market stall. Shambu is peering into a shop with male mannequins in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the moving mirror we see counters and shelves of men's clothing. The mirror stops at Max slipping into a kurta before an audience of Ravi, Manubai, and a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not extravagant at all. You can't go around all week in your tribal garb. Max sees a boy's face pressed to the glass: he indicates the shirt, for the boy's approval. The boy smiles a wonderful smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he looks civilized, doesn't he, Manubai?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost. Max looks at her.   She at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man leans down, whispers to the smiling boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure I look all right? The little boy nods. Max slips him several rupees... and he, Manubai, and Ravi fold themselves into her tiny car as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shambu runs to his dejected family. SHAMBU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! A man gave me these many moneys! HASARI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man? Why -- did you ask him for money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just gave it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? Shambu looks, but the car's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. We're not beggars. Shambu is devastated. Out of his own desperation, Hasari feels he's been a little rough on the boy. He holds him close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to the river. Wait for me by the tree. Don't go anywhere. Do you understand? Aloka, the boys nod. We WATCH them as Hasari heads off, quickly becoming a small figure disappearing into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUTE MILL DAY
dialogues.text: Starting to sink. We PAN DOWN TO Hasari stepping to a grilled window as the man ahead moves out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flaking gray wall, half-obscured with moldering files. The grilled window lets in a little light and the quiet supplications of those outside. An old CLERK at a desk. A voice calls out.       The Cler looks up, crosses to the grill. Hasari's tense face through the bars. A TRUCK RUMBLES past, drowning out the words... except these: "...trade union." The Clerk shakes his head sadly. On the verge of panic, Hasari hangs onto the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes of course. But I'm three days without work. I'll take anything. The Clerk digs in his pocket, presses two rupees on Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, now go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want you to give me -- The next man in line forcibly moves Hasari out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this city, a man with a family can't be proud. Take it! The Clerk waves him away, turns his attention to the next man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manubai's face.   Then Max's.   Then hers.    Then his. Looking at each other.   Five days.   Kiss.    Ravi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you have three days to get me into bed, and I'm betting you can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right for you to use my mother as your tour guide and meal ticket, because she'll get something nice out of it. But what would I get? He stares at her a moment, then gets up, goes around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gee,    I don't know. Maybe I could say    something so amusing that you'd    laugh so hard it would break that    hot poker you have up your ass. She stares at him. He bends to kiss her. She doesn't pull away... but after a moment he realizes she isn't responding. He continues the kiss, but he opens his eyes... to find her staring at him. He pulls back. They stare at each other another moment, then Max senses someone in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RAVI
dialogues.text: Staring at them, disappointment filling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: The same sound of frustration and ennui he made in the ashram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His arm around Max, Veejay guides the young man toward a waiting taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I understand, but you know how women are. Do you have enough money? Max gives him a non-commital shrug.    Veejay winks, stuffs the money into Max's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare feet... and then sneakered feet step over the sleep- ing bovine, who turns a disinterested eye up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is guided by a grumpy hall PORTER wearing an off- white shirt and bellbottoms through the walled and well planted courtyard of an inexpensive hotel. Max gives the cow a bemused eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is utterly utilitarian. The Porter turns on a ceiling fan, sending an army of cockroaches scurrying for calmer terrain. Max clearly doesn't care for cockroaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It pleases you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fruit basket? No mini bar? Max hands the Porter several rupees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bar? Of course -- many, many. But make care, Sahib. Please, for me. If it is lady you like to know -- yes? -- you let me. Huh? Very sweet girl, good nature, very sweet. Or boy, very good... Max puts a finger on the Porter's head, turns him for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No like boy? Something then for smoke -- mmmh, very good for smoke!

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: Max eases the Porter out.   As the door is closing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you like two girls -- look a little Chinese, but very great pleasure. Max smiles his smile and disappears the Porter behind the closed door. The smile disappears and the FAN gets his attention; it has an annoying rhythm and sound. He flicks the switch, but the fan continues to snap around.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stares at it... and startles us by suddenly flicking out a hand and grabbing the blade, stopping the fan. He lets go. The fan is still. He carries his knapsack to the tub; it has brown stains along the middle and the water has a brown tinge as it flows out of the tap. He sits on the edge of the tub, dumps his knapsack on the floor, picks up a half-dozen pamphlets from the ashram.

dialogues.speaker: PAMPHLETS
dialogues.text: Guides to inner peace.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: He wings the pamphlets at the trashcan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari comes around the corner of a warehouse, a smile on his face, clutching some bananas and dried grain. His relief -- and ours -- is short-lived.

dialogues.speaker: TREE AND BANK
dialogues.text: The space where he left the family has been cleared and taken over by trucks. He's lost his family.

dialogues.speaker: HOWRAH BRIDGE ROAD
dialogues.text: A group of Hindus are   celebrating a puja, the women singing canticles at   the top of their lungs; the men tossing a little boy   happily back and forth... as the panic-stricken Hasari   rushes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife, my children... Hasari rushes on.    Suddenly we --

dialogues.speaker: UNDER BRIDGE
dialogues.text: His head turns and his eyes look this way, that way... until out of the near silence, we hear a distant, extraordinary word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daaaaaaddddddyyyyy! The word catches Hasari's ear. He looks into the sea of people along the river bank under the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daaaaaadddddddyyyy! As in a dream, Shambu rises up out of the sea of bodies ... and runs to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daaaaadddddyyyy! Now, Aloka, Amrita, Manooj appear, rising up out of the sea, ending Hasari's nightmare. A warrior returning from battle, Hasari engulfs the little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to remain where I left you! I told you to stay there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police came!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We said we had to meet you, but they didn't care! They were mean! As before, Hasari tries to engulf the rest of his family in the protectorate of his arms. In the b.g., Arun and his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These friends have found space. They will share with us. Hasari looks at the tiny space. The roof is cardboard and cloth and half an old movie poster featuring the actor Kumar Kapur. Hasari looks at his tiny bit of food, debates a moment... then puts his hands together, addresses these generous people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be proud if you would share our food with us. Everyone looks at the food; there is no disguising their hunger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distant transistor MUSIC as we PAN DOWN: The Pal children sleep despite the QUIET MOANS and nightmare CRIES around them, the two boys huddled together, Amrita close to her mother. Hasari comes out of the dark. Aloka looks at him. He shakes his head. He slumps beside her. Aloka strokes Hasari, looking lovingly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the first time I saw you, on the day of our marriage. Wearing a bright yellow turban. You asked me my name and you said, 'You are a very beautiful girl and I am wondering whether you will find me appealing.' He strokes her tenderly in return... but now, overwhelmed with despair, she begins to weep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? She doesn't want to say it, doesn't want to wake the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss the village.    There I could help. Hasari pulls Aloka close, strokes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky turns red. The Porter looks up, shakes his head: Poor young man, stuck with only a trumpet for company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits on the floor in a corner and plays as we hear the sound of a fierce WHISTLE and a SCREAMING ENGINE.

dialogues.speaker: BULLDOZER
dialogues.text: A gigantic earthmover lurches into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swarming police.

dialogues.speaker: PALS
dialogues.text: Awaken -- startled, disoriented. Aloka gentles the children as Hasari moves instinctively toward the threat.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: A black ambassadorial car pulls up, out of which steps a BABU. A microphone and speaker has been set up. Another car unloads several politicos with party banners. A minion hands the Babu the mike; he wants to get on with it before this turns into a political rally. Hasari is close to him, as is Arun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The municipality has directed us to carry out the destruction of this settlement. All of you must go -- now! For a moment there is a babble of fear and frustration. Then from Hasari's side, Arun confronts the Babu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what reason? The Babue appears disconcerted.   He's not accustomed to the poor asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this settlement is impeding construction work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not moving! Why should we move? Who is the municipality? We are! This is our home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're driven from here, where should we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you five minutes to gather your things. Then, the settlement comes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should you alone be burdened with such a task? Let me help! Arun begins to tear his shelter apart, and to heave the pieces at the Babu, who retreats. Others soon take up the call to vent their frustration, hurling things at the police and at the driver of the tractor. Quickly we've got a full-scale riot. The police wade into the crowd, pounding people with their sticks, Arun one of the first to get hit. He staggers into Hasari's arms.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING PALS/ARUN AND HIS FAMILY
dialogues.text: Unbelievable! Panic-stricken, Hasari and Aloka gather the children and their few belongings... as beside them a woman goes down from a stick to the head; Aloka stops instinctively to help the woman, but Hasari grabs her, trying to shelter her and the children as well as Arun's wife and children, clutching Arun to him as in the chaos they manage to escape.

dialogues.speaker: BILLBOARD
dialogues.text: On the billboard: A maharajah sleeping snugly on a thick mattress. From his dreamland he inquires solicitously: "Have you ever thought of a Rajah Double Spring as a present?" We PAN DOWN and FIND the Pals and Arun and his family, panting, terrified, beneath the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, are we going to die here? Hasari can see on everyone's face this question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Today, I'm just a mangy dog on the street, but soon, I swear, I'll look other men in the eye! (a beat) I swear. Yet on his face we see the extraordinary pressure to make this promise reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari reaches the head of a line and receives a small handout. Turning away, he  studies the morsel of food. His head aches, his belly screams with hunger... but he takes only a single bite, then carefully wraps the rest in a cloth and knots it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He feels a tug at his elbow.   It's a 15-year-old BOY wit thick, scholarly spectacles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why live like a beggar when you can live like a maharajah? Hasari stares at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: HASARI'S ARM
dialogues.text: A needle injected, blood flowing into a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari seated on a stool, watching his blood leave his body, his face broken out in perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were only taking a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pay more, we take more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm feeling a little dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafik and a thin man chatting easily and exchanging ciga- rettes with another attendant. His vision BLURS.

dialogues.speaker: HASARI AND NURSE
dialogues.text: With his free hand, he begins to grapple for the Atten- dant to keep his balance, starts to fall... and the SCREEN GOES BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woozy Hasari gives Rafik his share; Rafik in turn gives the thin man his share. The thin man bows his farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood is the oil well of the poor, brother. Now, give me another three and I'll give you these. He opens his hand with its dirty nails. In it lie a little group of pills, like highly-colored sweets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitamins. Take these and you can give again in a week. While Hasari considers, Rafik pours the pills into Hasari's hand, takes the three rupees. Hasari downs the pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One week.   Here. The same time. And he's gone, leaving Hasari, woozy but at least, for the moment, blessed to count his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max lies on his messed bed, contorted, with his feet up over his head against the wall. A book lies open beside him. A half-eaten room service meal, many hours old, moulders on the bedside table. Max is babbling a mock sports case into his fist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the shotgun. There's the snap from center, the clock is running -- five, four, three -- he has an open man at the Notre Dame twenty for the victory... and he freezes. He freezes! Mr. Choke chokes. The fans go -- A KNOCK at the door. Max shuts up, falls off the wall. He crosses to the door. Opens it. POOMINA is 16, beautiful and exotic-looking behind her excessive makeup.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING MAX
dialogues.text: The porter pushes the girl gently into the room, smiling at Max, nodding. The door is closed.

dialogues.speaker: MAX AND POOMINA
dialogues.text: He may have been receptive to a "sweet, young girl," but not a kid in her teens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got an I.D. on you? (she doesn't get it) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty, sahib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I buy that. She approaches him seductively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do anything you want, sahib. She fingers the   Hebrew letter at Max's throat, on its gold chain. For    a moment, Max is mesmerized by this child; but then,   as she begins more serious ministra- tions, he pulls   back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, time out. Time, there's time out on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is problems, sahib?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is problems, yeah, just a couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please, yes, I can -- There's something desperate in her that makes him put a finger to her lips and say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout some chow? (she doesn't get it) I was just about to order some room service. Food. I call, they come, we eat. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max smokes a Monte  Cristo and watches Poomina, like a frightened little  animal, devour the last of a Green Acres room service  meal and then wrap a small piece of fish in the paper  napkin.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks up at him, delivers a small burp.    Covers her mouth in charming embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you are ready for great pleasure, yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching you eat was my great pleasure. Now you go home. As he escorts her toward the door, Poomina is distressed. Max realizes she can't leave empty-handed. He pulls out some notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you. She hasn't given up, though, and as he takes the money, she stands on tiptoe and kisses him. Torn, Max begins to respond. He stops  himself, his grip on her causing her discomfort. His  breath comes in little bursts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very wet kisser. Work on it, get in touch in five years. He leads her toward the door. Like some lunatic comedy. she resists. He pushes. She locks her knees. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, cut it out!   Now, good night. He muscles her out the  door, closes it, wipes his lips. He stares at a parade  of cockroaches gliding along the wall as he listens to  her CRYING quietly on the other side of the door. He   debates... and he loses. Opens the door. Poomina stands   there; the tears stop and a lip- twitching smile lights  her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years already? Gee, time really flies when you have no moral conviction. She slides into his arms, pressing against him. With his shoulder, he closes the door, leaving us outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bare light bulb; a SCRATCHY vinyl RECORD on a turn- table.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Poomina watches Max do a sleight-of-hand trick with a coin. He tosses it up, brings his hands past each other, then holds out his fists; she picks on... but the other holds the penny. Fooled, she laughs. He does it again; she points to one fist -- empty -- then other -- also empty. Max reaches behind her ear and... produces the coin. She loves it, her laughter escalating. But then she seesm to read something in the b.g. where we see four thugs, two of whom will become known to us as THE GOONDA, a capo to the local "mafia" chieftan, and ASHOKA, son of the local Godfather. Ashoka works on a pimple on his chin. The Goonda meticulously cleans a spot of mud with spit from one of his expensive new running shoes. Max eyes the thugs eyeing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short guys!   Quit lookin' at us! This remark goes over big with the thugs. Max doesn't care. He knocks off the last of the beer in his bottle. The bartender brings them two shots of something in two unmatched glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Special drink for you, sahib. Only the most man can drink it. You make try. For me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, I would drink battery acid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who that finish first.   I bet! She puts her glass to her lips and, in a childish, exaggerated way, mimes waiting for him to commence a drinking race with her. The two of them toss off what's in their glasses. The bangla in Max's glass is stronger than battery acid. He does an elaborate routine involv- ing the pain, the surprise, the sheer awfulness of the drink. But puts it down with mock machismo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't think so -- oh no, nay, nay! I never lose the truly irrelevant contest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have fun some more.   I bet again!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns to the bartender, calls for two more. All the while, in the b.g., The Goonda and his two thugs watch emotionlessly and Ashoka works on his acne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sings "Take It to the Limit" with enormous inebriated sincerity as Poomina helps him out of the bar. There's a big black motorcycle parked outside. Max glances at it as they start down the alley. As he looks back to the road ahead, he finds The Goonda in front of him. Max isn't so drunk that he doesn't sense what this is about. He looks behind him. Indeed, the other two goons are there. Ashoka straddles the big cycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well well. Seek punishment and ye shall find. Knowing what's  coming, Max nevertheless unleashes a beautiful howl  and tries to trample The Goonda off- tackle. From   behind, he's hit with a length of stick. He goes down,  looks up through blasted eyes at Ashoka as two sticks now  land against his shoulder and his head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pals sleep beneath the sign. Hasari awakens from restive sleep to the sound of a FIGHT. He gets up. The others awaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go -- what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like someone needs help. Hasari bolts for the corner.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEYWAY
dialogues.text: As Hasari turns into the head of the alley, he can see three men beating someone, a fourth man standing off to the side, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's being beaten here! As Hasari runs down the alley, the MOTORCYCLE FIRES UP and SCREAMS OFF and the three goons take flight.

dialogues.speaker: HASARI AND MAX
dialogues.text: Hasari runs up, reaches out to Max, who's barely on his feet. As Hasari touches Max, Max turns and belts Hasari in the nose, nailing Hasari to the wall as Max collapses at Hasari's feet. Hasari grabs his nose with one hand and kneels beside the fallen Max... as a shadow moves and startles Hasari. He peers into the dark... and Poomina steps into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crucifix sways. Now Max's eyes RACK FOCUS TO the cherubic face of JOAN BETHAL, peering AT the CAMERA without sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max on a cot in a tiny, spare room, a butterfly bandage under one eye. Joan, Irish, short, stout, hovers over him. Behind her, Hasari Pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, junior, welcome to our country. Max manages to sit up.   Wishes he hadn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I like the way the room moves in circles. (checking out his accommodations) I suppose I should inquire where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in the City of Joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that geographic or spiritual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now we require that each visitor decide that for himself. This gentleman and a young lady brought you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I do that to your nose? (as Hasari nods) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hasari shrugs, smiles... and a gigantic rat drops in Max's lap. He leaps to his feet and against the wall. The rat scurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that -- a Shetland pony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have to inspect it more closely, but I believe that was one of our economy-size rats. Max clambers for the door.        Too late, Joan thinks t say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your -- Max cracks his head on the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks -- got it. He ducks outside for some air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE
dialogues.text: In the dawn light, he finds himself in a small square in a slum, an open sewer running before him. He's repulsed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon the expression, but Jesus H. Christ. From the tea shop, SURYA, a stout old Hindu man dressed in Western clothes, raises a hand in greeting to Joan. On the door Max and Joan have come through: "City of Joy Self Help School & Clinic." Across the way, a young m is dandling a baby on his knee, rubbing its back and sniffing at its neck. Small group of children around a blackboard with a teacher, MARGARETA, doing numbers. RAM CHANDAR, the rickshaw puller, readies to go out to work. Trying to orient himself, Max turns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to find perhaps fifty people, largely women and children, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He knows them by type:   patients.   He looks at the sign on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, I'm a corporate executive. Doctor arrives at half seven, but only three days a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is obviously one of those three days. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. What brings you to our country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to find my white light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes.   I take it you didn't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kept opening the doors and windows of my spirit, but couldn't see a goddamn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do in America? Max is slow to answer.   Discreetly, Hasari hangs back, listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, how exciting. Must be something illegal. Are you a criminal of some sort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose that depends how you define the word: I'm a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. How long are you here? Perhaps I could recruit you for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. You've got your non- practicing Catholics. I'm a non- practicing doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How very distressing.     Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found out I just really don't like sick people. Well, I'm outta here. I owe you one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine ever divining how to collect, but there are a few of us Indians, you know, who believe the tourist trade ought to be encouraged. Max turns to Hasari. Hasari is incredibly shy, can barely meet Max's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.     Let me... He goes for his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please. Max finds his pockets empty. Then reaches for his wrist -- his watch is gone -- and then his throat -- his chai is gone, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid they cleaned you out. Ram, here's your first rider. (to Max) Take this. She holds out several rupees toward him.      All eyes on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, it's all right.     You'll owe me two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max in the rickshaw, Hasari running alongside Ram, an exuberant smile slashed across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I can keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep up, of course. Anyone can run at this pace. But you think it's easy to run and to pull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do it.   I could pull it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, give him a shot. He's as fast as you and looks twice as strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you still pay me when he runs you into a ditch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.    I trust the man. Suddenly, Ram comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you, come, step in here. Hasari looks on Max with enormous gratitude. Ram puts the shafts down, has a short coughing fit, spits some phlegm, looks at Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're taking something for that. Ram waves him off as Hasari lifts the shafts to his hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, fine, pull, go. Hasari tries to pull, but the center of gravity isn't easy to find. This is enormously difficult and Hasari's very clumsy at it. The street is crowded. The traffic is beginning to back up behind them. The driver and conductor of the tram let fly a tirade of insults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, mister! What did I tell you? Come on! What do you think this is -- some village street? You've got to move quickly. He turns to Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, it takes a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say he can do it. I'll bet you the fare he can do it. (play by play) What do you think, rickshaw fans, can he do it? The crowd isn't in for fun. Hasari strains forward. The rickshaw moves with him. Ram moves alongside, shouting instructions and oaths. A cop comes on the run, screaming at Hasai... which makes Ram importune more strongly and Max joke more vociferously. Even under this incredible pressue, Hasari gains confidence and begins to move quicker, earning shouts of approval from Max and Ram, who now has trouble keeping up as they make their way through the maelstrom, an avalanche of oaths following them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first all we see are feet on a marble floor. The Goonda's in his running shoes, then Ram and Hasari's bare feet. This is the partitioned splendor of an old house sprinkled with the relics of a grand colonial past. Everything is baroque, rotting and somehow impressive. Hasari has never been anywhere like this, and is caught between curiosity and fear of breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men enter a large room shuttered from the sun- light -- dusty and packed with a ramshackle assortment of furniture. Two fat blue titmice perch in a cage next to ambitious plaster portrait of Napolean. Sitting behind a desk is Ashoka, leaning over a mirror, squeezing a balky pimple. Near a large window, his 60-year-old father, GHATAK, in a European jacket and dhoti, works with intense concen- tration at repairing a pair of broken glasses with a twist of fine wire. The three new arrivals stand silent and respectful before the desk. At last, without raising his head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a tongue between you then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I am wondering, sir, we are, is it possible you might have something for my friend? Ram indicates Hasari, as if there might be some question to whom he's referring. Ashoka attacks the pimple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain it for your ears, sir. My cousin from Bihar has just arrived in our city --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've brought a small present -- of respect. The Goonda places a small bundle of rupees on the desk. Ashoka allows himself a disinterested glance at Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you want to be a human horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes! I have personally witnessed his excellence -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't talk? Can he neigh at least? (to Hasari) You -- do your ears function?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Babu.    Can I... uhm...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neigh!   Like a horse. Ashoka pulls back his lips, shows his teeth and imitates a neigh: "Ne-igh! Ne-igh!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, Babu, I can do that. Would you like me to imitate a horse? Finished with the pimple, Ashoka wipes a finger on his shirt and takes a helping off a plate of sweetcakes as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind him, The Godfather walks up to the desk, putting his glasses on. He barely glances at his son, but waves him out of the chair. Ashoka doesn't like it, but he steps aside. As he does, he turns a look of hatred on Hasari. Through no fault of his own, Hasari has made an enemy. Ghatak chews on a pan and casts a benevolent eye on Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift your longhi. Hasari does.    The Godfather looks at his legs and thigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wise men of our nation say that nirvana is the attainment of a state of supreme detachment. For me, nirvana is counting each evening, one by one, the rupees earned by my two thousand and forty-six rickshaws. Hasari doesn't know whether to respond. A glance at Ram tells him not to. Ghatak gestures for Hasari to lower his longhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are with family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a wife and three children, Babu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they must eat, heh. The world is full of open mouths. He chews on this a moment, then opens a drawer... and holds a small, tinkling rickshaw bell toward Hasari. Hasari understands that, incredibly, he has a job. His breath is so shallow, he can barely utter his gratitude. He takes the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall be eternally grateful to you. From now on, I shall be as the youngest of your brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay loyal. These days, it's a crop nobody plants. The Godfather turns his beatific and Godlike smile on Hasari Pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transitor MUSIC. The Pals load the rickshaw that stands at the road with Ram in it. There are embraces with the bruised Arun and his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the BELL TINKLING as the rickshaw, pulled by Hasari, carrying Ram and Aloka (holding Shambu) arrives (Amrita and Manooj trotting beside their father). Surya, Selima, other neighbors greet them as they come. The Pals glance into the school at Joan, who's teaching an evening class.

dialogues.speaker: WITH PALS
dialogues.text: Reverentially, they follow Ram inside as Joan watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens. Moonlight. Faces peer through the door. Ram lights an oil lamp. In the glow, the family looks around their tiny space. Hardly able to suppress smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone has blessed us. A job, a roof, a school. Soon I'll be able to send money home... (looking at Amrita)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and put away a little bit for your dowry. In their excitement, the boys run.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: and up to the roof, under the stars.   We LOOK UP WITH them and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN DOWN TO Max on his balcony playing his trumpet as we continue to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty tattered street kids faces shining with en- joyment. They run and shout as they pursue something just out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cause of the excitement is Hasari running TOWARD us, feet flying, as he pulls the rickshaw, loaded with a huge sack. Manooj and Shambu are clinging to the sides of the machine. Ram stands   in the center of the square. He shouts a command and   Hasari struggles to bring the rickshaw to a stop. It's    not easy and Sunil -- who's arriving -- has jump out of   the way to the accompaniment of apologies f Hasari and   Ram and hoots of laughter from the children. Outside the clinic, a line of perhaps seventy-five wait patiently, watching as Hasari takes off again. The wheels of the rickshaw hit a rut. Hasari loses control, the sack tips back and Hasari is lifted into the air, feet kicking as he tries to regain his balance. Aloka and Amrita, sitting near the bawling Ram, can't hold back their laughter.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The square is set with obstacles. As Ram shouts instruc- tion, we see Hasari negotiate them with much increased skill. He stops in front of a small group. It's his family, plus Joan and Surya. With an exhausted smile, he signs to Aloka and Amrita to get in. They do, and Hasari takes them triumphantly around the circuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari's triumphant ride continues and we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari rubs the moonstone in his ring on the shafts, then touches his heart and his forehead. A SCHOOL GIRL in uniform, approaches the rickshaw stand. We also see several other pullers, Rassoul, Chomotkar, Ramatullah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickshaw wallah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let Hasari go! The line of rickshaw pullers  turns to Hasari. The other pullers wish him well as he  comes forward. His heart pounds; ever so politely, he  helps the School Girl into his carriage. She gives him   the address of the St. Pius School.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't know where that is. You're my very first passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.   Well, I hope I bring you luck. She gives him a sweet smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way, and then to the right. His moment has arrived. He looks at Ram... and thrusts his hips forward, setting off into the insanity of the traffic, eyes flicking left and right. A HORN RAILS at him and a taxi tries to run him down, calling and laugh- ing as Hasari jumps in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Feed the police! Other pullers laugh,  call after Hasari... and as he approaches the first  corner, he manages to pull out a rupee and deposit it  into the hand of the impassive traffic policeman and  then turn right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The School Girl hands him a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my home address. Pick me up promptly at seven each morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, you can depend on me. The girl runs into the school  yard, met immediately by friends. Hasari looks around   at the clean, bustling school, at all the children in  their crisp uniforms and a look of great yearning comes  over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is trying to explain to the waiter what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beef. You know -- cow? Minced, little salt, pepper, slap it flat like this, throw it on the grill, flip it. Now, though, he just glimpses the shiny gas tank and engine of a motorcycle around the hip of the waiter. He leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashoka, astride his motorcycle, GUNNING the ENGINE as a boy runs out of a store with an armload of cassettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it on the grill, I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: WITH ASHOKA
dialogues.text: He pulls the boy's ear, REVS the ENGINE to go... and senses someone close. He turns to find an American hovering at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I have to say you really don't look Jewish. I believe that's mine. He reaches for the necklace with the Hebrew letter. Ashoka recognizes Max. Looks around for help. There is none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me. No one touches me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Max grabs Ashoka... who breaks free, and GUNS the CYCLE down a side street. Max gives chase, his aching ribs slowing him a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashoka, glancing back, begins to open up some distance. Yet, Max hangs tough, weaving like a broken field runner through the mass of bodies and vehicles. Now, suddenly, he loses Ashoka. He has to make a choice about this corner or that one. He chooses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COP steps into his path.   He sees Ashoka up ahead. hopelessly out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... great... good...good timing ...him! He can't talk and breathe. He points desperately. The Cop glances where Max points, but he makes no move to give chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see your passport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passport? I'm in the middle of a high speed chase. That guy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passport please. A crowd has begun to form. In the distance, we see a group of girls carrying cricket equipment COMING AT us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in my hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passport, please, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready my lips: I do not have my passport with me at this... (he gets it) Ah, I see, said the blind man. The Cop obviously is doing this at Ashoka's behest. Max starts around the Cop. The Cop, however, sticks his club in Max's face; there's fire in Max's eyes... but a hand takes the Cop's stick before Max can make a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING OWNER OF HAND
dialogues.text: The girls with the cricket equipment (and Margareta, the teacher). The hand belongs to Joan Bethel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all right, junior, so you'll owe me three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scribe finishes writing a note home for Hasari.   The scribe hands it to Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: NOTE AND MONEY ORDER
dialogues.text: "We are well. Manooj does not go in the cinema. I am earning my living as a rickshaw wallah. It is my honor to send you this."

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: With great pride, Hasari pays the scribe, seals the money order with the message in an envelope, licks the flap, and puts the envelope into the mail slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surya plays his zither. Max and Joan sit at a table. Max pops little boiled candies into his mouth from a dish on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it was just a whim in the beginning really -- to try to convince them not to be so bloody passive, that they could pull themselves up on their own. I get a little money from a Swiss organization. Now it's become a bit more than I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got to be like trying to drill a hole in water, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just need a few more hands on this little life raft we've set afloat here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They stare at each other. Shambu has become one of Surya's tea boys and refills their tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I've come to think in my middle age, Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, no, earthly idea. You're pretty much outta my league, thought-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are really only three actions open to a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only three -- okay.   And what are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To run, to spectate, to commit. Max peers at her a moment, then around the square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has it occurred to you that this obsession with charity is really a flaw in your character?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charity! It's not charity, dear child, it's love. You're very badly twisted around, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of us sure as hell is. The clinic's part-time doctor, SUNIL DASGUPTA, comes out of the clinic after a very long day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off for home, Sister Joan. A pleasure to meet you, Dr. Loeb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, God bless, Doctor. (a beat) Generous young man.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he watches Sunil head away, Max senses something com- ing at him from the side. A soccer ball almost hits him; he jumps up, handles the ball athletically.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE
dialogues.text: He begins to play with Manooj and several other children. Shambu leaves his post in the tea shop to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the American doctor?    Are you coming here to help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm the visiting American soccer star, El Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you go to the cinema in America, El Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was your age -- two movies, plus cartoons every Saturday. Aloka and Amrita are cooking on an open fire bucket. Max almost knocks the fire over. Aloka looks at him, apolo- getic, shy... as Manooj knocks Shambu down at Max's feet. Max scoops the little boy up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go, little guy.    Ut -- what's this? Reaching behind Shambu's ear, Max produces a boiled sweet Aloka watches this with a smile; their eyes touch again.. as Manooj lets out a cry at the sight of their father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram and Hasari return home. Hasari can hardly walk. Shambu runs to his father, explaining excitedly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, there is the doctor from America. He saw two movies every Saturday. What's in your fist? Open, Daddy! Shambu pries his father's fist open:   seeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeds?   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we can watch something grow.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAM'S HUNT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Children leaning down as smoke wafts up. We FOLLOW the smoke DOWN TO Max's cigar. Aloka and Amrita laying the food out. Shambu rubbing his father's aching legs as Hasari and Manooj plant the seeds in Hasari's little tea caddy full of earth from home. Max is watching this "family" huddled around the father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another few months, I'll be able to pay off the moneylender in my village and go home and open a grocery shop. All around me sacks overflowing with all kinds of dal and rice, aromatic spices, piles of vegetables... and at night, I'll lie on my back beneath the trees sniffing fresh aubergines. This beautiful picture burrows into Hasari's mind.   For a moment, he goes there -- home, to the village...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my wife will let me come within a hundred miles of the place where she herself resides. Ram laughs, Hasari smiles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amrita, I saw a beautiful wedding sari today. Amrita is terribly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was six hundred rupees only. He laughs at the impossibility of the price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's only 40 dollars, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send it to you from America when I get home tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very generous but no, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repayment for punching you in the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have repaid me by sharing our supper. Joan indicates that Max should let it go.    Hasari ever so carefully waters the tea box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Big Brother, I myself would be willing to accept a gift. Could you give me five rupees in a note -- ten, perhaps. My ankle is badly swelled; the higher the number the more the swelling sinks. Max has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a cent on me.   I'll owe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much? Now everyone's attentions is taken by a CRY from Shambu, who expels his breath, his terrified eyes directing our attention to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an amazing sight. Two lepers: ANOUAR, bearded with a sharp intelligent, unmarked face, makes his way along on a small wheeled board, at an amazingly fast pace, ahead of SAID, a huge, mute leper. They stop some feet away. Lepers aren't often welcome. Out from behind Said steps Poomina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan Di, my sister!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sees Max, gasps, throws herself behind Said. Joan looks at Max -- he starts to speak, she points a finger that silences him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Poomina who brought you to us. She has herself and her sister to support. It's all right, Poomina. Anouar, what is it? She moves to them.   They're all three badly out of breat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Meeta! It's her time. But something is wrong. The midwives don't know what to do! Dr. Sunil, could he help, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Sunil isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeta will die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan turns to Max, who hasn't heard the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, I wouldn't ask, but it's an emergency. A pregnancy gone awry. It's a leper. Could you have a look? Max is clearly thrown by the sight of the lepers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any experience with leprosy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Christ, son, because she's a leper doesn't mean she's not built like a woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can run and get Dr. Sunil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too far.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly, impulsively...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could help.    I've had three babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that. They're outcasts, they're unclean. There are murmurs of assent from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh nonsense!    It's not contagious! A beat -- everyone fixed on Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a doctor, how can you not help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon reflects off the dark puddles of muddy water that line the side of the railway tracks. Anouar propels his board with astonishing agility along the path, Said and Poomina running with him. Max, Joan, carrying a first aid bag, Aloka and Hasari following, slipping and sliding on the rough ground with its puddles and sewage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little procession arrives outside the three rough huts, made of bamboo, plastic sheeting, cloth, wood and cardboard. A few shadows materialize. Lepers -- staring silently. Anouar points into a hut. Joan and Aloka precede Max inside. Max forgets to bend and bumps his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only light is the feeble waver from a candle. The blind Meeta lies on a rough mattress on the ground. Her ragged sari is pulled up to her middle. Her face runs with sweat, her hair is plastered to her face. A girl with black eyes is fanning her with a piece of wood. Meeta sends up a SOFT, uninterrupted MOAN. A wedge of blood-soaked cloth is between her legs.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A middle-age leper is leaning over her -- a midwife, encouraging Meeta with a string of commands in their own language. Max kneels, Aloka at his side.   His breathing becomes shallow... but then he pulls off  the blood-soaked bandages. Between Meeta's legs   he can just make out the bottom of a foot. The child   is breached. Maybe already dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she die? Max goes into reflex actions. Joan has opened the first aid kit. There's a flashlight among the medicine, alcohol, compresses, scissors, etc. He hands the flash- light to Aloka as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joan) Pull me two c.c.'s of Coramine. He nods at Aloka; she illuminates the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh, uh-oh, who's this coming' down the lane? Why it's -- is it possible -- way over here, in India -- yes, it's Mr. Choke. He comes to a stop. Everyone stares at him. Meeta moans. For a moment, he stays frozen. Aloka reaches out instinctively, wipes the sweat from his eyes. This gesture seems to free him; he looks at her, looks at the room and its expectant, trusting faces...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to have to turn it -- the baby. Tell her she has to relax these muscles as much as she can. He doesn't finish the sentence. Aloka speaks softly to Meeta as Max takes Meeta's arm, makes a tourniquet. Joan hands him the syringe and he injects. Hands the syringe back to Joan and begins to work at turning the baby. Aloka takes Meeta's hand and it's a moment before we realize Aloka, with her fine hand, is holding Meeta's fingerless palm.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: A small group waits, trying to determine from the sounds what's happening inside. Anouar pours tea from a pot on the small fire, offers the cup to Hasari. Hasari stares at the cup, doesn't want to be impolite, but more than that, doesn't want to touch the cup. He shakes his head, smiles. Anouar drinks off the tea.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Sweat pours down Max's face into his eyes. He shakes it out. Aloka leans forward and, with her new sari, wipes the sweat away again. Max nods thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her again to breathe in short little bursts now. He demonstrates. Aloka does the same to Meeta. Meeta tries to cooperate. And suddenly Max has the baby turned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right!   Now, tell her to push. Aloka translates. Meeta pushes.      The midwife, the lit girl, Aloka lean forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again.   Yes!   Again.   It's coming.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: No one is sitting now. Everyone hangs close to the door. Only Hasari remains apart, seated on a tree stump in the middle of the quad. He coughs; suppresses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the head. Come on, little baby, come on, little baby. Be alive, be alive, be alive. Aloka wipes the sweat away again. He looks at her, his voice squeezed out through his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
