dialogues.text: We've got it, we've got it.     Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He seems as released as Meeta. Then he gives a last gentle tug and a CRY squeezes out of the little piece of life in his hands. Max is fairly overwhelmed by the life in his hands. Poomina steps close, a smile on her lovely face, and touches the baby in Max's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, Joan, Aloka and Hasari walk in silence down Nizamudh Lane. There is only the mingled  sound of COUGHING, MOANING, and a TRANSISTOR RADIO nearby playing a popular song. Outside the clinic, they  stop. She takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a non-practicing doctor, that was pretty practiced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never been so scared in my life. It's a warm, open moment between them.   But now there's the ongoing desperation of her needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, please, won't you change your mind? We desperately need another doctor. Full-time. Think about it -- just give us a couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do it. Maybe you've got it in you to be a saint. I just don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what do you want? What are you going to be when you grow up? Good night, Aloka, Hasari. Joan goes inside, leaving Max, Aloka, and a very uncom- fortable Hasari alone a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for allowing me to go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could make a helluva nurse. A little smile comes over her face; no one's ever paid her that kind of compliment. She goes into Ram's hut, leaving Max and Hasari now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think perhaps you are a good man. Hasari brings his hands together and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max hears Joan praying inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, my brother, you who I am trying to believe are the light and salvation of the puking world ...

dialogues.speaker: THE PALS
dialogues.text: Aloka sits huddled with her husband while their children sleep; they listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please see that we are living in madness and darkness here...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and we need help. Om, Jesus, om and amen. Suddenly, he hurtles into motion. He runs down the alley, his stride stretching out, swallowing up the distance between here and the world beyond the City of Joy in great gulps.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A busy, urban airport as opposed to the small country airport in which we saw Max earlier. V.O. we hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes, that's right, yes! I turned in your ticket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small place; it's sweltering, and it's packed with hundreds of families shoulder to shoulder. Though Betsy's trying to be discreet, it's not a very private place, as we see by the number of people watching Max and Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought it, I got a refund!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I want to go home with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go home with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- how -- name it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy yourself a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would love to do    that, Betsy Ilene, boy would I    love to do just that, but I'm    financially embarrassed at the    --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use your credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What credit cards? You know I maxed them before we left. Just lend me -- BETSY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! You won't pay me back; you never have. Oh, Max!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're calling our flight. I want to go home with you, Betsy Ilene Kahn. Because I have a vision. It's... He's trying to woo and charm her.    He mimes a kind of house shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you and me, Betsy Ilene Kahn, nibbling toward each other through a quarter pounder with cheese, chugalugging a frosty light beer -- great taste! Less filling! Bowling! I want to go bowling, Besty Ilene Kahn! He fires a strike through the watching crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want... Oh, my Lord Amighty, I want so many American things --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, stop it! You have no earthly idea what you want, Max! And stop calling me Betsy Ilene Kahn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call me Betsy Ilene Kahn like you just met me yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I call you?   My girl, my significant other --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get cute! You get cute and I swear to God --- you told me once I look like my mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do -- so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See -- you don't understand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I possibly not understand a conversation as easy as this one, Betsy Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Na ya don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stood by you for three years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I supported you through your internship!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? It was never working. What have I been thinking all these years -- that you'd change? You're the most self-pitying, self-destructive, self... She can't find anything fierce enough, so she abates, tries to get it together to make a dignified exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've taught me something, Max. You never finish anything. Well, I quit. I've found my light and I'm free of you. She heads for the gate, people parting to give her a wide berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you at least call my mother and ask her to empty my savings account and wire --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it yourself, Max. Call her collect. You should have called her weeks ago anyway just because she's your mother! (to herself) White light, white light...! She hands her ticket and boarding pass over and she's through the gate. Max turns to find the audience fixed on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guerilla theater, folks. 'All the world's a stage.'  Don't know if that word reached you here yet. If you'd care to show your appreciation by a small donation... Many smiles... and several instant offers of rupees. beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, what the hell. ... Swallowing his incredible embarrassment, Max takes the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line is long. At this moment, Joan is checking a child's throat with a tongue-depressor. Aloka is walking beside her with a fistful of depressors and a bag for disposal. Hasari and Ram are getting ready to leave. Anouar appears at Joan's waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Joan Di. Dr. Loeb said many of us could be helped; that all it would take is money for medication. Anouar hands Joan some newspaper in which something is wrapped. Joan opens the paper. Inside is a good deal of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please buy the medication for us. If we cannot come here to receive it, perhaps Dr. Loeb would come to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be happy to buy the medication, but Dr. Loeb is not part of this endeavor, Anouar; there is only his cherished memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then perhaps I am having visions. Anouar's focus is up the lane.   Joan follows his focus to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max approaches. A buzz    about Max's heroics; hands comi together. Max raises a    hand in benediction, makes the sign of the cross. Max    claps Hasari on the shoulder; Hasari brings his hands   together and gives Max a genuinely pleased smile.    Children circle and touch him Manooj and Shambu among   them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning! Good morning! Heckuva morning! Getting ready to practice medicine without a license, Sister Joan? You don't see me soliciting conversions, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well, I do so love to be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, for starters, pick me out someone with something easy I can heal, make me look good. (to Aloka)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloka, you're my assistant, let's go. Aloka smiles, she nods, she accepts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, knock it off, give us a bit of hush. (as he does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm a bloody bathing beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so I got left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart girl... So how long am I stuck with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks -- or until Mom sends me a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not worth the aggravation of your prattle every day. Six months -- and not a day less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. Six weeks -- and that's my best offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months -- and that's my final offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and Mary. The Lone Ranger rides again. And now smiles creep onto all their faces as Max goes inside, followed by Joan... and then Aloka -- after she looks at Hasari, gets his nod of encouragement. Too late, Joan says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your -- Thud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks -- got it. The children titter. The teacher, Margareta, admonishes them to pay attention and be polite... as we --

dialogues.speaker: WEEKS LATER
dialogues.text: The wheels spinning furiously and then stopping abruptly. Hasari, dripping with sweat, panting. The School Girl comes running toward him. After her, in the b.g., her MOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari, where have you been? I've been waiting almost five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, forgive me.   It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to school today. You're taking my mother and me to the Bara Bazar. I'm getting married!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am so pleased for you! Panting helplessly, Hasari smiles... as he helps the School Girl's Mother into the rickshaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, missus. Briskly, he takes up the shafts and sets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn right at that corner, Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's farther that way, missus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really. Turn there, please. Obediently, Hasari turns (as Ramatullah, heading the other way, passes; they wave) and Hasari pulls AWAY FROM us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps them out of the rickshaw in front of an expensive-looking bridal shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must remember this shop, Hasari, when it's your daughter's time. This is the nicest in the city. The Mother gives the School Girl a withering look and hustles her into the shop. Hasari can just barely hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say things like that. He's never going to be able to buy anything here.

dialogues.speaker: ON HASARI
dialogues.text: He watches from outside, a look of determination coming over his face. Suddenly a pair of fingers takes hold of his ear, twisting his face painfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashoka, with The Goonda and two henchmen, in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not working? How will my father eat this evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Babu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickshaw wallah! Called to work, Hasari starts for his rickshaw, but Ashoka hangs on to his ear for another uncomfortable moment... as he slips a rupee into Hasari's shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep working. Give this to Sister Joan and your friend the doctor when you go home. Now he hands Hasari a sealed envelope and turns his ear loose. Hasari springs toward his passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max with his stethoscope to Meeta's baby. Meeta in a brightly-colored sari and a lot of bracelets and Aloka looks on. Poomina clings to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just malnourished. Is she giving him the milk we gave her or selling it? Aloka asks Meeta in Hindi. Meeta clearly swears she's giving the baby the milk. Aloka pushes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all.     Most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her to give all the milk to the baby. Aloka does so as Max bounces the baby, coos to it play- fully. The baby pees all over him. Aloka translates quickly. Meeta starts apologizing. Poomina can't help laughing. Max reminds Meeta that that's once for each of the two weeks of the baby's life. Aloka soothes Meeta as she hustles her, Poomina, and the baby out, then quickly begins to wipe Max's face with a clean rag. This isn't something she's accustomed to doing, but she's doing it before she has time to think. Max finds himself conscious of her closeness to him... and then she becomes suddenly self-conscious and she backs off, ducks her head. He peeks up under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. He smiles.   So does she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunil stands outside the clinic, rolling his sleeves down. Anouar waits at a polite distance. Exhausted but exhilarated, Max and Aloka emerge with an elderly woman patient, Max singing Chuck Berry to the woman's embar- rassed delight: "They're really rockin' in Boston, in Philadelphia, P.A..." Sunil looks at his American colleague, smiles a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, I'll see you day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Sunil.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "... Deep in the heart of Texas, around the Frisco Bay..." Manooj and Shambu come charging at Max with the soccer ball, hoping to engage him as a playmate. Hasari returns home with his rickshaw. Selima waves at Max, indicates she's cooking dinner. Joan wanders out of the school as the kids are released and go charging through the square. Joan has the Pal kids in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very special supper for you tonight, Doctor Big Brother!   Will you stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I could, Selima,  because I'm sure hungry! Sixteen   hours of pestilence and misery  always make me famished. I have   to go with my man Anouar tonight.   I've got lepers to heal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you know how patient we are. Eat, eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Aloka) You're not tired, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you're not. Between Hasari and Aloka, there's just a flicker of tension; evidently, this has become Max's (and her) normal day. But he's also worried about the note from Ashoka. Joan joins them with the Pal children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think we've got three very good potential scholars here. Behind the children's backs, she points at Manooj and indicates the kid's really got a head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given him some time here, he'll be good enough for a proper school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than a father could hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen years from now: Miami, Florida, Dr. Manooj Pal, in association with Dr. Maxwell Loeb. For a moment, Hasari is swept up in this little reverie, then remembers reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her the note) From the godfather's son. For you and the doctor. Amidst instant concern, Joan opens the envelope.   Looks at Max. We hear the sound of BANGLADESH MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC is of days gone by, playing on an old RADIO. Sticks of burning incense send off trails of smoke. The godfather, MR. GHATAK, Looking infirm, wipes a tear from his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acha! Now we see   Max and Joan seated on cushions before the godfather,   tea in hand. Max catches a glimpse in an anteroom of   several thugs with several young girls, one of whom is   Poomina. She catches a glimpse of Max as she disappears   past a door. A moment later, her head peeks around the   door frame. She brings her hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! Poomina quickly disappears.   Max's attention is pulled back to the godfather...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that you're interested in expanding your clinic and free school, and that you intend to start treating lepers in the City of Joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd like to better serve the entire community, Mr. Ghatak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. That's very good. Admirable. And we'd be pleased to rent you suitable space. But you must understand that certain payments will go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand the rent would have to go up if we rent larger quarters from you, Mr. Ghatak, but why should we have to pay more protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More people, more potential trouble. Strangers. If I don't charge you, what will I tell others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can't afford it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely if you can expand, you can pay more. Joan throws up her hands -- how do you reason with this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I stupid, but isn't this protection money money we're paying you to protect us from you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We live in chaotic times, Miss Bethel, Doctor. I control the City of Joy and maintain it as a model of harmony. It's a miracle, but a very fragile miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are we threatening your miracle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admire your courage in choosing to work in such a violent place, Miss Bethel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your neighbors in the City of Joy, they're not educated, they're given to violence, to meanness, I can promise you they won't like having lepers among them, but because they know you're under my protection... He dispatches a globule of spit into the copper urn next to his right toe... and tries to get to his feet. The Goonda hurries forward to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, do you like our music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't say I've developed a craving for it yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's difficult to appreciate what we don't understand, isn't it? Let me put it another way: The world is a terrible place. Only the ruthless prevail. My son will make the arrangements with you. One of the thugs helps the godfather outside, where, in the b.g., we see him listening to his music and pottering in his garden. As Max and Joan turn, Max finds himself face to face with Ashoka, who wears Max's necklace and chai. There's a long pause as the two of them take the other's measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ashoka) I like your taste in neckwear. Joan puts a cautioning hand on Max's arm. Ashoka seems just the slight bit uneasy dealing with Max and so keeps trying to direct himself to Joan. He smokes a long Indian cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire package we're proposing will cost you three thousand rupees a month. Joan is taken aback by the sum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we pay you that, we won't have any money for supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm told you're very resourceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I see a solution. May I? What if we were to work out a profit-sharing arrangement? We give you a share of our net profit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you expect to make a profit off of lepers and the poor, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats the hell outta me, asshole. But you've obviously found a way. The question would seem to be whether Ashoka will have Max killed here or outside the house. His eyes on Max, Ashoka puts the cigarette out against the back of his hand... and smiles at Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone right off your rocker!? These people don't have a sense of humor. Are you trying to get yourself killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so... but with me, any duplicity is possible. He tickles her; she knocks his hands away; he tickles her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, you... you... you nudnick! He doesn't stop, and as she storms off down the street, he stays right on her, tickling away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark and claustrophobic. The air vibrates with the SQUEAL and CLATTER of METAL. About twenty kids sit in a line, back to back, manipulating aseries of lethal and unprotected lathes and polishers. No one can hear his neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari, with Shambu in the rickshaw, arrives to take the children home. As he looks inside, he notices...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far from Amrita sits a handsome boy (Subash). He catches Amrita's eyes. Amrita is sweetly embarrassed to find her father staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: ON HASARI
dialogues.text: But he can't help but smile. At the same time he's re- minded moment to moment of his various obligations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three kids in the rickshaw. An ambassador car swerves in front of Hasari, forcing him to jam to a stop, jolting the kids. The Goonda sits in the back seat with Ashoka, who carves his fingernails with a switchblade knife. He crooks a finger at Hasari. Hasari leans close and Ashoka takes him by the ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gave you your rickshaw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Godfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who provides the food you eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Godfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember:   Loyalty. He gives Hasari's ear a last tug... and the car continues on, leaving Hasari. He looks at his children, ashamed to have been cowed. Manooj fixes his father with a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning over, listening, taking in the aroma of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max's cigar. He sits slightly apart from Joan, Sunil, Aloka, Ram, Hasari, Selima, Margareta, Surya, SALADDIN, ASHISH and Shanta, Aristotle John, MEHBOUB, Anouar, and Said. Hasari is stretched out, Aloka rubbing his screaming legs. Throughout the following, their eyes meet and deflect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Godfather is at least civilized. The son is vicious. Remember the last elections -- the Molotov coctails, the blows with iron bars. They'll throw us out. We won't be able to find anyone else to rent to us. We'll just have to agree to pay what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saladdin's right. Neither nature nor the people with the power have any conscience. We have to pay. A sigh escapes Surya.   He shakes his head.    Eyes flick at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, Doctor Big Brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we must try to break the Godfather's hold on us. This is startling and is met with a babble of cautious agreement and dispute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, hear me out. But I think we have to be very cautious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do you proceed with caution against these people? You can't. You have to risk everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You try to negotiate with these people, you make compromises with them, they'll eat you alive. Stand up against them now and they'll fold. I guarantee it. Underneath, they're cowards, they got no guts. We show them we're strong and the'll just move on to easier pickings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We?   You have an airplane ticket. Still, he's clearly piqued a lot of support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Max, this is not American gangster television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, if you're wrong, you don't have to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not wrong. You bow your heads, you plead with your Gods to do what you won't do yourselves. You put up with this nightmare as if there were no choice. I'm telling you, if you don't stand up to that little pimple face now, he'll own you for the rest of your lives. Everyone stares at him. Many of them want to buy his commitment. There's another large sigh from Surya. Aloka and Hasari's eyes bang off of each other, she silently urging him to speak. He's deeply conflicted and deeply frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though I am invisible to some of you and I don't have a complete set of legs to stand on, I stand with the Doctor Big Brother. Maybe nature doesn't have a conscience or those with the power, but don't we? Said, the giant mute, mades an unintelligible sound in his throat, but clearly he's agreeing with Anouar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with Anouar and Max Daddah. I think it's worth the chance. Silence... until Aloka and Hasari's meet again and, out of his terrible fear and conflict, he says very shyly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it permitted to speak? There are quick nods around the room.   With great diffic Hasari says his piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my children to be educated and cared for; this is our home, we have never had such friends. But many of us owe a great debt to the Godfather. He is strong and could kill us... But we must choose. I trust my Big Brother. I say we must stand up. There's still dissension, but somewhat more support. Said makes a fierce, unintelligible supportive sound. Surya sighs again. Eyes flick at the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Joan, what do you think, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think Max has hit on the heart of what we're trying to build here: a self-help society. Each of us has to decide for himself. As for me, I suppose I think, really, that if the bastards are going to suck us dry, I'd like to get in a couple of good left- handers before I turn the other cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who will rent to us! Surya clucks his tongue and shakes his head; everyone assumes he is preparing a heated refutation of the resisters. His sighs, though, have been a building commitment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a property I will    rent you for two hundred rupees a    month, and not a rupee less. As     for protection... you are on    your own. Many of the faces are uncertain -- Hasari's notable among them.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. COWSHEDS
dialogues.text: A) Two cows are shooed out of the ramshackle building as bustling activity on the new clinic begins. Cleaning the place. Debris being torn out, hurled into a pile in the street. B) Said, with the strength of three men, holds up a heavy beam while Hasari tries to secure it. Max, hot, smelly, and hating the place, stands in the middle of the room, wishing he were elsewhere. The beams starts to slip. Max leaps to Hasari's side. C) We see    that Max and Hasari are thrown together agai in some    carpentering task in uneasy camaraderie. A finger    pokes Max on the back. He turns to find Poomina    holding out two cups of tea. D) The whole    group shares a meal, prepared under   the direction    of Selima, though the lepers remain   separa from the    normals. Anouar leads the lepers in    singin a song.     Joan and Margareta pick it up, as do   severa other of    the normals. E) Equipment from the old school/clinic being moved from the square down here. F) Max and Aloka do one of those dances where two people with arms loaded try to go around each other. Finally he says he'll stand still and she should go around him. They both laugh. Hasari watches. G) As Max puts medicine into a cabinet, Ram peeks in, nods his approval, "helpfully" passes Max something Max can reach just fine himself, shows Max an enormous hole in his shorts and hits Max for ten rupees. H) A small truck carrying a charitable organization's logo on the side is being unloaded of powdered milk and various other things.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: Hasari and Max    move the last cot upstairs and into place beside a    window that will come into play at the end (It looks    down on the street). Hasari nods to Max, indicating he    should look.

dialogues.speaker: J
dialogues.text: Everyone gathered as Shanta and Ashish put a banner above the door: "You are invited to the festival of this world and your life is blessed." The assemblage applauds and embraces.

dialogues.speaker: K
dialogues.text: Hasari smiles at Max, brings his hands together, but doesn't embrace the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone lingers, adults and children. Max plays his trumpet, accompanying Surya on his zither. Manooj hovers over Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Big Brother, aren't you going to smoke your evening cigar? Max points at his trumpet, continues playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Max indicates his pocket. Manooj takes out a cigar and a clip. Clips the cigar, holds it out to Max, who indi- cates Manooj should light it, and keeps playing. Manooj looks at Hasari, who nods. Shambu holds a match to it. Everyone watches as if this were a major event. Manooj takes a puff, chokes, offers the cigar to Mehboub, who takes it, puffs, passes it. Everyone relaxes, enjoys the peacefulness of the smoking and the aroma wafting upward. Ram taps at Max's elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has come to me tonight to write a letter to my wife. Ram produces a mangled one piece letter -- envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He thrusts the paper at Max.   Max takes a pen from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- shott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- what is the word -- that word -- when land is watered... with canals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Irrigation"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, that word, I want that word in the letter. Max looks at him, nods, waits.   Ram stares at Max; waits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like to say to your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Max Daddah. If I knew what to say to my wife, I'd never have left home. Everybody laughs, though Ram's remark hits Max on a deeper level. Manooj slides in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have to go home, Doctor Babu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he doesn't live here, Manooj. This is not his home. A look between Max and Aloka; Hasari's eyes flicking at both of them... as Aloka's eyes come to Hasari. The cigar reaches Ram. As Max starts to write, Ram takes a large puff and blows a huge ring out of his mouth. We FOLLOW it.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: A whole row of faces on rooftops enjoying the cigar. This as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the WHEELS we see Max come briskly out of the hotel carrying his doctor's bag. He's met by the sight of Hasari between the shafts of his rickshaw and Anouar and Meeta perched on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On no! Lepers! Lepers in my neighborhood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sshh! Doctor Big Brother, please, we are pretending not to be lepers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, I didn't get the concept -- of course, not lepers. I think you're going to fool a lot of people. I have only one question: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come to take you to the dispensary in grand style on this special day, haven't we, Hasari?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Na, I'll just trot alongside Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please, get in. Max climbs into the rickshaw beside the two lepers and Hasari pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeta's very excited by this ride through Calcutta. You see, she's never been sightseeing before. Meeta, of course, is blind.   Max, Hasari, Anouar laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're incorrigible, Anouar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I know, thank you very much. As the rickshaw disappears into the sea of people and vehicles, we hear Anouar and Max LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margareta, Manooj, Shambu, Shoba, several other kids and, at the end of the line, Poomina, all carrying water on their heads toward the City of Joy. Suddenly, someone whispers to Poomina. One of Ashoka's thugs. She glances after Margareta and the other kids who are turning a corner and steps into:

dialogues.speaker: ALLEYWAY
dialogues.text: Where Ashoka waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You taking that to the clinic? (as she nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it there? (as she nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they love your smile, don't they? She's fearful now and doesn't respond. He grabs her, the water pitcher crashes to the ground, he puts his knife into her mouth and lays her face open on both side with his knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloka comes TOWARD us leading a group of lepers.     And stops. Her hand goes to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CLINIC
dialogues.text: Two hundred normal people lined up outside the gaily be- decked dispensary -- many mothers with small children in their arms. Shanta sees Aloka, gestures to indicate the incredible turn-out. The normals at the end of the line turn to look at the approaching LEPERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too beautiful to believe.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As if indeed she were right, their path is suddenly cut off by the Goonda and a commando of thugs, armed with sticks and iron bars, backed up by a group carrying banners with slogans proclaiming in Hindi, Urdu, English: "We Don't Want Lepers Here!" There's a sudden uneasy silence. Behind the thugs a short distance is the policeman who harassed Max earlier and another cop. Joan hurries forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sister to the poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Bhose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those people aren't coming into this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are going to be treated at the dispensary. You have no right to stop them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari arrives with Max, Anouar, and Meeta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Aloka, take them inside. The Goonda puts his hand on Aloka.   The policeman in the b.g. keep their distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hands off her, you waster! Joan is seized by a sudden fury and grabs the Goonda. He grabs her much harder. Said growls and pushes forward. Several thugs turn, step in to neutralize him. Joan elbows the Goonda and tires to westle free of him. As a reflex he raises his hand. And as he does, it's seized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max (with Hasari in the b.g., confused, conficted).   Max slings the Goonda against the side of a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a mistake, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mistake's yours, putz. (to Aloka) Get these people inside. Aloka starts forward, leading the lepers. She's stopped by a sudden blow from the Goonda's stick across her shoulders, knocking her to the ground, bleeding from the neck. Hasari bolts for his wife, gets caught up in the melee. Max swings   around on the Goonda and for the first time realize how   strong he is, and that he knows how to box. The Goonda   goes down and violence erupts. Anouar is chopping at   the legs of one of the thugs working on Sai The massive   Said tears free and starts to beat the crap out of the   two thugs holding him. The noise brings everyone out of the square, those lined up at the clinic, the children from the school. Sunil comes flying out of the clinic. A stampede of those waiting outside the dispensary and those normally in the crowded alley ensues. Shanta runs inside for help. Shopkeepers barricade their shop windows. One of the thugs pours gasoline over Anouar and  lights a match. Hasari kneels beside Aloka when he sees   the match ignite the tiny leper. Without thinking,   Hasari hurls himself on top of Anouar, rolling him in  the dirt and against his own body to put out the flames. Joan shouts, demanding the violence stop. She's hit from behind; she decides talk isn't going to do it. She grabs a piece of lumber and starts to fight.

dialogues.speaker: DISPENSARY
dialogues.text: An EXPLOSION in the doorway, scattering anyone who remain in the area of the dispensary doorway, badly wounding Mehboub. More people with sticks. Hasari goes down under    severa bodies. Max reaches Aloka, helps her up, sends    her tow the clinic. He tears an attacker off of Hasari    and the fight back to back a moment. A SECOND EXPLOSION    near them... and through the smoke Max sees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashoka astride his motorcycle, behind his dark glasses, with more thugs, these with Molotov cocktails and pick- axes, ready to raze the clinic and school and the surrounding neighborhood. Sunil drags Mehboub inside. People chant: "White Monkeys, go home! White Monkeys, go home! No lepers here! No lepers here!" The thugs cock their iron bars and bricks and Molotov cocktails. Max picks up an iron bar of his own and starts for Ashoka. Suddenly, there's a DETONATION followed by a BLAST of air so fierce, Max is thrown to the ground. A bottle of GASOLINE has EXPLODED just behind him. He's enveloped in smoke. An assailant bears down on Joan with a cutlass. As the assailant is about to strike, Hasari seizes the attacker and hurls him backward. Ashish steps in and slashes the assailant with his own weapon, startling, even repelling Hasari. From all over   the lane, young fighters have come and jo the fray, not   bothering to choose sides but merely enjo the release.    Hasari lunges for a woman under attack by boy, arriving   too late to stop the boy from plunging hi knife into the   woman's belly. Hasari fights his way to the woman, but   she staggers into the mob. Max knocks down one of the thugs only to have  another ha grasp his shoulder. He turns, fist cocked to   find Poomi her hands holding her face together. Slowly,   she takes hands away. The sides of her face have been   laid open. Max sweeps her up in his arms, heads for the  clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, little girl, little girl... Joan is suddenly beside Ashoka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll pay! All right then, so by all means, protect us! Ashoka raises a hand,   The Goonda blows a whistle, and the fighting stops as   suddenly as it began. The com- batants are breathing   heavily. There is silence but for the groans and cries   of the wounded and grieving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a world such as ours, everyone needs protection. For the fee we discussed, from this day forward, I can assure you nothing like this will happen again.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A beat... Saladdin is at Joan's shoulder.     Ashoka poin a finger at Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. I warned you about the company you keep. He REVS his MOTORCYCLE and SCREECHES away, leaving Hasari staring after him in his dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People peer in through every opening. Mehboub's chest is bandaged. Sunil squeezes through the packed courtyard and hallway, Ashish carrying a wounded woman behind him. Hasari steps into a doorway, us WITH him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, blood crusted on her face, sutures Poomina's awful facial wound as Aloka prepares a compress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she... Her face, will it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she's very careful and doesn't do anything to open the wound, the scarring will be minimal. (to Poomina) Do you understand? You can't... You have to stay here. (to Joan) You make her stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't goddamn try, Joan!   Goddamn do it! Poomina peers through her pain at Max, his hands putting her back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a litany) I hate this place, I hate this place, I hate this place. Max looks at the doorway and he locks eyes with Hasari. Max breaks the contact. Hasari stares at him as we hear the godfather's MUSIC on the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand tap, tap, taps against a ledger.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Ashoka sits behind a little table, picking absently at his face. The Goonda is slouched near the table, smoking a cigarette and fiddling with a thin switch. (It's dif- ficult for him to show Ashoka the respect his inherited position gives him.) The Goonda has a bruise under one eye from his altercation in the City of Joy yesterday. The air is filled with the MUFFLED SOUNDS OF the STREET. FROM here, we can see the evermore enfeebled godfather in his "throne room," wrapped in a cashmere, listening to the radio. Ashoka looks up, stares impassively at someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.    What have you got to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, we see who Ashoka's speaking to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them that your father provides us with a great deal and that -- Ashoka slams his hand on the register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this minute, you   are off the list! You will leave    your rickshaw here... where it will   be reserved for a man who deserves   our trust. He stands up.       Hasari is near tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Babu, this is as if the ground has opened up. I have to speak to Mr. Ghatak! Hasari starts for the house. The Goonda stops him and, quickly, has Hasari on his knees, his arm twisted pain- fully behind his back. Ashoka jumps at Hasari, grabs his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's ill! You are speaking to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a family!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decision is made. I have made it. Now get out before I have Mr. Bhose break your legs. He gives Hasari's ear a vicious twist and slams his head against the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The side gate opens and Hasari is shoved   out. Stumbling he runs to the fence, peers through. Two    men are pulli his rickshaw into the courtyard. Hasari    watches as a steel shutter is pulled down, cutting his   livelihood fr sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numb, compromised, defeated.    Perhaps the low point of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flickering candlelight illuminates the "Raft of Medusa." Max rails at Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't... I don't want to... I don't want to care! I don't want to care this much! I just don't want to be invested in you people. In people! I became a goddamn doctor because my goddamn father wanted me to be a goddamn doctor because he was a goddamn doctor! He was the goddamn king of doctors! It's too goddamn hard! Out of breath, out of words, Joan reaches out and takes Max to her, brings him beside her on the cot. Beneath the "Raft of Medusa," she sits with an arm around Max, as if he were her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everyone's cut out for this. You did the best you could. Better than many. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do the best I could! I did what I always do! I shot my big mouth off and did a half-assed job. And what I want to do now is I want to go back to America and make money and live a life without entanglements and demands and people hanging on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) You know, the fact is from the minute we're born we're shipwrecked. Some see that as a lifetime of drowning, of fear, others only to endure, but to triumph. It's all in the individual spirit, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it: To run, to spectate, to commit. (raises his hand) Running spectator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, by all means, go home, Max, and go with my blessing and my eternal friendship. The candlelight flickers against them as they sit side by side. Neither speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the tea shop, a group relive the day's events. The children sleep. Aloka sits outside, worried about Hasari. Max comes out, meets Aloka's eyes and looks away.   She's heard the conversation. Hasari, drunk, comes down the slope.   Face to face with Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took away my rickshaw. Aloka's hand flies to her mouth. Hasari peers at Max with his drunken gaze. It's a terrible moment for Max, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want me to do about it -- get it back for you? Max takes away a step.   Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm going home. Because this isn't my fight. I got one person to look after -- me. Hasari stares at Max. On the roof, the children listen. At the tea shop, the late-night talkers listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm running out,   okay? Because I'm a coward, this   is me, this is what I do, I get in   over my head, I let people down,   I run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I trusted you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was your goddamn mistake! Max walks away, leaving Hasari desolate.   Aloka comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how I'm going to pay the rent, how we're going to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have what is saved for Amrita's dowry. The thought of using the dowry is yet another awful blow to Hasari's hopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children must leave the school; they'll have to work. And you will not have anything to do with the clinic or those people anymore. Ram joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I earn is yours, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't support all of us. You have a family in your village, too. Hasari touches his friend and goes into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in his pain, he spots his tea caddy in which he planted his seeds over a month ago. He bends over to tenderly touch the growing shoot and water the earth. He looks up and the three children are staring at him. What will their father do now to keep them alive?

dialogues.speaker: HASARI'S ARM
dialogues.text: The needle injected, Hasari's blood flowing into a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari seated on the stool, watching his blood leave his body, his face again broken out in perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: His face immobile, his thoughts distant. The Attendant starts to pull the needle out. Hasari stops his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take more. The Attendant shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take more. The Attendant looks at Rafik, who shrugs, nods... and allows the blood to flow on out of Hasari's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely ambulatory, Hasari starts down the street, but has to stop, lean against a wall. Through his woozy haze, he thinks he sees an apparition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, in the entrance to a building, is Gangooly. Seeing a potential victim, he swoops in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not well, brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still stealing from refugees? Gangooly looks at Hasari, recognizes him, and gives him an amazing smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I remember you, of course -- hello! I am delighted to see you -- yes. And tell me immediately, please -- your little family, your beautiful children, everyone eats, yes. Come, have a cup of tea or a little something stronger, we must celebrate. Gangooly starts to move, to position himself for a get- away. Hasari blocks his egress, unsmiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well, you're angry    at me, yes, I wondered if that was    still on your mind -- I am full    of regret about that, yes, even    a little tormented. What can I     say? I have the spirit of an eagle    trapped in the body of a crow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend, I am lame and I am poor. Does that mean that I shouldn't survive? Huh? When a man is struggling in a rough sea, he clutches onto what he can or he drowns. You don't look so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my rickshaw. Gangooly gives Hasari an appraising look for a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ach! I  have an offer. No, listen!  Shiva be my witness, you must at least think about this. Please, I can help... Or my name is not Mr. Gangooly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which, fortunately, it is.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Gangooly guiding Hasari onward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remove the children from the school -- no, why? When you, the father, can make a small sacrifice. Nature has foreseen your plight. For she has given you two eyes, yes, and two kidneys. But. To live, you have need of one only. I have a friend who sold his kidney -- this one -- and now -- believe me, this is the truth -- he lives in a brick home... which he owns. That smile. EXT. SKELETON WAREHOUSE (MITRA & CO. EXPORTERS) - JUD

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: A forbidding face appears at the grill, stares out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari and Gangooly enter. A repulsive smell almost makes Hasari gag. Gangooly takes Hasari's arm and steers him through the gloom. Hasari discovers the origin of the smell. A line of skeletons arranged along the walls. Tables stacked with bones: skulls, spines, rib cages, hands and feet. Each skeleton sports a label with a price in U.S. dollars. Crouched among the bones and packing crates are men work- ing. Some smoke, some have masks over their faces. They scrape and clean and decorticate. They skillfully assemble their grisly creations, emotionless but like artists.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: THROUGH a dusty, glass, interior window, we see, almost in mime, the manager examining Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a smile, the manager produces some papers. Hasari shakes his head, starts for the door. Gangooly stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, take some time, think about it. People all over the world, anxiously waiting, willing to pay. 15,000 rupees for a kidney. 25,000 for an eye. Gangooly winks, peers at Hasari with a single eye, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heat haze on the road. As we FOCUS, we FIND Max, Joan, Aloka, also with their thoughts. Joan gazes out the window of the taxi. Max looks at the back of Joan's head a moment, then looks at Aloka, who sits between them. She deflects his eyes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari has forbid her to have anything more to do with us. He'd be very angry if he knew she was seeing you off. Max looks at Joan.   Looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: First we see joyous people greeting arriving passengers; parents greet a young man returning from college abroad. The way clears and we CLOSE IN ON Max, Joan, and Aloka, a tiny island in this sea of people at the moment of their parting. Max empties all the money out of his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for Poomina.   When I get home... He thrusts the money on Joan and Max offers his hand; she goes through the hand to embrace Max. Then Max and Aloka look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did good things. (chokes up, but manages)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming to our country. And now Max heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparsely populated.     They sit in isolation at a table over a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like  he's royalty or anything, so  I'm not persuaded we have to wait  for the plane to actually take  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   We should go. Yet, they   remain another moment... then get up. Joan puts her   arm around Aloka and they turn to go. The look on their   faces suggest they've come face to face with something   startling.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Max.   Standing inside the departure doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were those three choices again? Their faces. And his with just a wistful version of his old grin... and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari returns.     Goes into Ram's hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds his family... and Max.     The two men stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need Aloka at the clinic. (as Hasari stares) All right, they, the patients, need her. She's a good nurse. (as Hasari stares) Come on, man, this is between you and me. Why take the kids out of school, why punish your wife? Hasari holds his anger in; he moves to a mat and lies down, his back to Max. But Max doesn't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a little money, I can get it from the States...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a question of money. We'll survive on our own. That's it. Hasari lies with his back to Max. After some moments of silence, Aloka indicates Max should go. And he does. After another moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's right. The clinic is for everyone and if I am needed -- Hasari bolts up, a look of anger on his face we've never seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I'm your husband and you'll do as I say! Unless, of course, you've become an American wife and then you'll do as you please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from them. They are not part of us. They will only be good to you as long as you please them. The children, Aloka are frozen, she very close to tears. Hasari lies back down, again turns his back on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small colony alive; a line of patients outside a door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max unwraps a bandage from a leper's partial limb. Looks around for Aloka. She's not there. Said is acting as his nurse. Points at his instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand me the scissors, please. Helpfully Said hands him the tweezers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scissors, scissors. He demonstrates. Said fumbles through the instruments, picking up the scissors by the ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that end -- No, that's fine, thanks, I've got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max comes out with his last patient.   Anouar waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Daddah, you are finished? (Max nods) Follow me. Anouar takes off down the lane and disappears quickly into a little building, Max following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max follows Anouar past bubbling cauldrons and heaps of animal skins. The place stinks fiercely. Anouar and Max exit into...

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL YARD
dialogues.text: Two young men (the two pullers Chomotkar and Ramatullah) ... and something covered with a tarp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't steal this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police, Sahib, they stole it. We stole it from them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The pullers whip the tarp off. A battered rickshaw, the springs poking out of the seat, the broken wheels lying in the body, the finish scarred and gouged, one shaft broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max comes into the square. Aloka and Selima are pre- paring meals. Manooj, Shambu, and three other boys playing. Ram is trying to jolly Hasari, who's deep in his own reverie. Max stands in front of Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to show you something. Just take a minute. A beat as Hasari fixes Max with an empty stare and the family waits to see if Hasari will respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.   Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a PADLOCK being UNLOCKED. DARK SCREEN. Light flashes. Max and Hasari appear in the doorway. Surprised by the light, a few rats scurry off. Some- where a dog BARKS. Slated, shafted light. He indicates a corner.

dialogues.speaker: THE RICKSHAW
dialogues.text: Piled up in its ruin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good with my hands. You're good with yours. What do you say? Hasari looks at Max, part resentful, part touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were to go on the street with this machine, I would end up in a gutter with my throat cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's yours if you want it. You know the license, the cops, all that can be fixed. You'll own this -- it'll have nothing to do with the Godfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Daddah, I'm just a small man. Don't try to tempt me again with big thoughts. Hasari starts to leave.    Max blocks his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't want me to quit.    Well, I came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But can you be trusted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. Hasari can see the hope and desire in Max's face. After a moment, Max steps aside. Hasari bends his head and makes off. Leaving Max and a small sigh of disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her morning absolutions, bathing in the foun- tain. The process is extremely sensual, though there is not even a glimpse of her nakedness as she moves her clothing around, cleansing this area, then that. She glances up to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, in an Indian shirt, heading for the square; rather naturally, he brings his hands together in the Indian salutation. He carries several bottles of distilled water, a large value pack of bar soap, and a carton of medical supplies. As he passes, his eyes hook on Aloka's. He lifts a hand in greeting. After a moment, she ducks her head. He turns and continues on coming face to face with Ram, an enormous smile on his face. With him, Hasari. He glances at his wife in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hasari) Going to look for work?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When Hasari doesn't answer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is. Ram has a small coughing fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you taking your medicine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, but look at this. He points at the wheel  of his rickshaw; the rim is cracked. Scornfully,   Hasari walks on. Max and Ram glance after him. Max   digs out several rupees. Ram takes them and goes.   Max looks after the two men as they disappear. When   he turns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he finds himself face to face with Aloka. Without a word, they start walking side by side toward the square. It's several seconds before she says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very proud. They walk on in silence -- two friends, separated by a gulf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men moving like ants into the bow of the ship.   Hasari i locked out, turned away without work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge gouge in the black mud, sunlight streaming through steel girders across it. Hasari emerges from the ground, looking for someone. Stops him. The foreman shakes his head, no, before Hasari even has the chance to ask for work.

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: Then we see he's standing outside Mitra & Co., starin it, wondering if it's time to sell part of himself. No! We see on his face a look that tells us he will not be beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street children's school now takes up two rooms. Children peer out of one room now as, to the accompani- ment of Surya's zither, twenty or so girls are doing some Indian classical dancing, under the eye of a young Indian teacher. Across the way, in the other room, some children are translating Bengali words into English. A boy is writing on the board. It's Manooj. We see that Shambu is in the same class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM BEHIND, we watch Max take a wrapping off of Poomina's wound, Joan assisting him. Indeed, Ashoka extended Poomina's smile on either side of her mouth. The scars are healing as nicely as could be expected. Max did a fine job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have had a good doctor. Still no running, jumping, picking up anything heavy. And you stay here. You're going to help Sister Joan and you're going to school. Do you understand? A beat, Poomina nods.    But now a look of abject fear comes over her face. The Goonda stands in the doorway. Max begins singing "Sweet Little Sixteen." The Goodna stares impassively at Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to collect the rent, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.     Come with me, please. Joan leaves, followed by The Goonda. Max works care- fully at the fine line of scabbing on Poomina's scar... but then something takes his attention.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Manooj, with a small tin of food, looks this way and that... and then sneaks into the shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a, TAP, TAP, TAP. The door is half open. The padlock is hanging on its chain. Max opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, frightened, Hasari presses himself against the wall, as does Manooj. Hasari is wearing a wet dhoti, caught in the middle of straightening the wheel rim of the old rickshaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the door! Max is very surprised but, needless to say, pleased. looks at the rickshaw, looks at Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the door. The Godfather has more eyes than a pineapple. Max quickly closes the door. The half light is broken by thin beams of light that dance with dust. Hasari studies Max a moment, then moves to put the first wheel on. Instinctively, Manooj moves to his side, takes hold of the rickshaw so Hasari can slip the wheel on. Hasari nods and goes for the other wheel. Manooj moves around to the other side, hefts the carcass. Hasari slips on the second wheel. Hasari looks at Max. Max brings his hands together and starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was saying to Manooj that if a man bows down too many times, there will come a day when he will no longer be able to stand upright. The two men look at each other... and then Hasari gets on with his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised Manooj and Shambu I'd take them to the movies. Is it all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) If a man makes a promise... Max brins his hands together and starts for the door. Hasari picks up one of the worn seat boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're TRACKING WITH a moving bag of peanuts behind a row of boy's heads. On the screen in front of them, a "medi- eval era" sword battle between the great Kumar Kapur and a legion of bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of CRACKING NUTS as we MOVE FROM Manooj to three kids we've seen in the neighborhood (two boys Manooj's age and Shoba, who's Shambu's age) and then to Shambu, each kid dipping into the bag in his turn. Finally: Max's (and on the other side of him, Amrita and Poomina.) The bag arrives... empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Thanks, guys. Who wants to go for more peanuts? No one. We're talking about rapt attention.   We hear NUTS CRACKING. Max smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and the boys walking home after the movie, the boys dancing around each other, acting out the fight sequences all of the sword-fighting against Max, who battles them all over the street, in and around cars, Poomina and Amri looking on shyly, as El Max fights to save their honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't decide if I want to be Kumar Kapur or a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha ha! You can be both! Manooj Pal, swashbuckling physician!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so much fun, El Max. I wish my daddy were as much fun as you. Max stops the fight, takes Manooj by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish my father loved me like your father loves you. Your dad's a very special man. And now, en garde! As the battle continues, the bright beams of a truck come at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time out, men. Off the street till this truck passes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The kids move toward the wall of the building they're passing, but the truck seems to turn toward them, seem- ing not to intend to pass, but to hit them. The look on Max's face lets us know he senses something terrible is in the offing here. He shouts for the kids to get out of the way, shoving the kids closest to him into a doorway. He turns to Shambu, who's behind him, calls to him. But in a panic, Shambu doesn't move into the shelter   of the building on his right... but tries to run across   th street. Max leaps for the little boy too late... as    th truck just misses Max and clips Shambu hard, sending   th little boy flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manooj runs   ahead of everyone as he charges into Ram's hut, crying   for his father. Behind Manooj come the others, Max   carrying Shambu in his arms. Hasari and Aloka, Ram,   Joan, others in the square hurtle out of their huts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do anything here. He's got a compound fracture, he hemorrhaging. We've got to get to a hospital -- now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get a taxi at this hour.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET
dialogues.text: He pounds along,  the wheels wobbling and squeaking, urging people out  of his way. Max runs alongside Hasari. Aloka sits on the  seat with Shambu, whose quiet moaning fills her ears.   Blood drips down the rickshaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several taxis waiting for clients outside a row of restaurants. Hasari and Aloka watch as Max argues with the drivers. They won't take a bleeding passenger.

dialogues.speaker: SAME STREET
dialogues.text: The race to the hospital continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arrive at the gates of the huge, Victorian hospital. People sleep outside the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wards are full, as are the corridors. Patients on beds and stretchers everywhere. Most have at least one member of their family to look over them. In a side room, Max is arguing with a porter who tells him he can't help him.  Max slaps some rupees into the porter's hand, tells him to take him to the person in charge. Shambu is fading. Aloka smooths the sweat from his brow, trying to keep Shambu alive by force of will and love. Then Max is back, standing over her with another man. It may take a moment before we recognize the ATTENDANT from the Blood Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll admit him, but we have to pay for the blood. I gave him all I had. He wants more. Do you have anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Joan gave me this. Aloka holds out a fistful of rupees. The Attendant blows through his lips, indicating it's a paltry sum. Max grabs the money and shoves it at the Attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't got any more! The Attendant doesn't move... until he sees Max is about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this child dies while you stand here, I'll kill you. The Attendant is smart enough not to push any further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I need an X-ray room and I need an O.R. nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not possible. You can't give care, you're an American. You must be an Indian doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take me to one! As Max takes flight with the Attendant, Aloka strokes Shambu and Hasari hovers. We CLOSE IN ON Shambu's inanimate face and HOLD a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max hurtles down the corridor with a young INTERN in tow. Almost a kid, he's been up for days. But he's going to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, please. Max scoops Shambu up and rushes down the corridor behind the Intern, leaving Hasari and Aloka looking after him. His arm comes around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari and Aloka wait.   People are starting to move abou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my wife, Aloka, you and my children are all my wealth. But if Max Daddah and Big Sister Joan have need of you, you may go to them. Max comes out of the hospital.   The two Pals stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pinned his leg. Couple of months, he'll be better than ever. They want to keep him today. We're a good team. Gimme five. He smiles, holds out a palm for them to slap. They look at the palm, unsure what this means. Yet, each takes Max's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole community is here, around the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it was an accident. I think they were aiming for Max. So, what we have to ask ourselves is whether his presence is endangering all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even from my low vantage point, I know this: It's the son. He's mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Daddah is our friend. If they're trying to harm him, then they're trying to harm all of us. We must stand by him as one.

dialogues.speaker: TWO PAINTBRUSHES
dialogues.text: dip into a little box of paints. The boys look on as the two men paint an intricate design on the shafts. Shambu sits in the rickshaw seat. He wears an ankle to hip cast. Manooj is spelling words and urging Shambu to follow suit. Aloka is putting out a tray of food. Ram, Ramatullah, and Chomotkar slip in, quickly close the door. The two pullers focus on the rickshaw, Ram on Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Daddah, please, very important, only one moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to cost me every rupee I didn't make today. Ram thrusts an envelope into Max's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter from your wife. Ram nods nervously. Max looks at the postmark as he slices it open with a finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is postmarked six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what have you been doing -- incubating it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was afraid. Ram waits, his hands twisting each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'My dear husband...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's very hopeful so far!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Your words brought tears of joy to my arid eyes.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm in love! My words brought tears to her arid eyes! (then fearful) What does that mean -- arid? Manooj throws his hand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know!   Dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. Her eyes were dry, your letter irrigated them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaah! He snatches the letter, crushes it to his heart.   Notice the finish work on the rickshaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a puka nasgar. What a curse that you can't use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going on the streets tomorrow. This gets everyone's attention.    The pullers shake thei heads, they're worried for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. I don't want you to think I'm crazy, but I don't think that truck was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Ashoka was after me. You can bet he'll be after you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to speak to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I go with you? I'll go with you. Can I go with you if I shut up? A beat... and Hasari gives him a small nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghatak is literally carried out of the house by an orderly and placed into his car. There's a driver and there is the Goonda. They start down the street. We're WITH the car. Suddenly, the driver slams on the brakes and from:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Hasari and Max blocking the street with the new rickshaw. The Goonda jumps out of the car, comes threateningly at Hasari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babu, please, I beg you, hear my words! As the Goonda is about to land on Hasari we hear a feeble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. The Goonda backs off. The Godfather waves Hasari and Max close. Hasari brings his gleaming rickshaw to the window of the car, Max at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I say first, Babu, I wish you long life and good health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acha! They take me now to the scientists. They stick needles in me, take pictures of my insides, study them, and then tell me what I know.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Godfather stares at Hasari, flicks his eyes at Max. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you gave me work, I swore I would be as your youngest brother. Your son thinks I have been disloyal. He took my rickshaw. With my friend, I have remade this one. I beg you to let me go again onto the streets. I have my family. The old man looks at the rickshaw, at the obvious care that went into its renovation, at this unlikely team of refurbishers. He reaches a shaking  hand out toward a shaft. Hasari brings it close. The   old man rubs the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Babu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may say, it has an allure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An allure, Babu -- thank you. The Godfather stares at Hasari, then at Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is chaos. We struggle to build something permanent, then our bodies betray us, our sons betray us. (to Hasari now) Yes, you may take your rickshaw out. If you can face up to my son. The Goonda gets back into the car and the car pulls away and we are left with Hasari and Max as moment. EXT. SKELETON WAREHOUSE (MITRA & CO) - DAY Hasari enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager stares at Hasari, as he consumes a pot of rice and vegetable curry. Gangooly hovers like a crow. Hasari stares at the contract before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a man dies and he's not burned, what do you think becomes of his soul? The manager turns his palms up, continues chewing. Hasari stares through the window at the row of skeletons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must provide for my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a noble fate. If indeed your wheel ceases to turn, you will help educate somewhere in this great world a fine doctor. Hasari bends to the contract and laboriously signs his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasari arrives to an outcry of anger. There are several dozen rickshaws. Among the passersby, we see umbrellas, as the people on the street try to combat the incredible heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
